Colette's NYC Food Guide

May 10, 2025 by Colette Chang

Iâ€™ve now spent a full year in this wild, exciting, and chaotic city.

I still wouldnâ€™t call myself a local â€” more like a one-year tourist who just happened to live here. I wandered through a lot of neighborhoods and ate a lot of meals. Some were nostalgic, some were surprising, and some were simply comforting in the middle of a homesick week.

Hereâ€™s a list of the places that stood out â€” categorized so you can find what youâ€™re craving, with honest notes from someone whoâ€™s still exploring.

ğŸ¥¯ Breakfast & Brunch

Liberty Bagels (Midtown & FiDi) My favorite bagel in NYC. I was skeptical of the rainbow bagel at first, but it turned out to be surprisingly delicious and totally unforgettable. I usually stop by when taking visitors to Central Park or Wall Street. I recommand try one sweet (Oreo, blueberry, or Nutella) and one savory such as lox, avocado, egg and cheeseâ€” and share with friends. They also do festive holiday bagels that are surprisingly delicious and photogenic.

Ellenâ€™s Stardust Diner (Midtown)
If youâ€™re short on time or budget and canâ€™t catch a Broadway show, this diner is a fun alternative. The food isnâ€™t anything special, but the live singing waitstaff give you a little taste of musical theater magic while you eat.

ğŸ½ï¸ Lunch & Dinner

Maison Pickle (Upper West Side)
My favorite restaurant in the city!!! The French toast fried chicken is unreal: sweet, spicy, savory, crispy, and soft. The buffalo mac & cheese is pure comfort. The garlic bun is famous, but I personally prefer the herb one more. For dessert, try the Oreo cake, even though the signature 24-layer cake looks cooler.

Prince Street Pizza (SoHo) The square slice here is iconic â€” thick, crispy, cheesy, and a little greasy in the best way. Itâ€™s probably too heavy for a typical Taiwanese stomach, but hey, youâ€™re in NYC! Embrace the junk food.

Sakagura (Midtown East)
High-quality Japanese food thatâ€™s still affordable. Come for the weekday lunch special! Itâ€™s surprisingly fulfilling and tucked away in a hidden basement, which makes it feel like a delicious little secret.

Mala Project (East Village & Midtown) The best dry pot Iâ€™ve had in Manhattan. Still not Asia-level, but flavorful and comforting if youâ€™re craving that numbing spice.

Maxiâ€™s Noodle (Flushing)
The best wonton Iâ€™ve had in the U.S. I made the trip to Flushing just for it â€” twice! Still need to try their Manhattan location.

Dhamaka (Lower East Side)
A high-quality Indian restaurant that delivers bold flavors and unique dishes. Definitely try the biryani - the pot is covered by bread! Really traditional way to make the dish. Also, donâ€™t miss the dessert! Itâ€™s exotic, but surprisingly tasty. A great spot when you want something different and exciting.

Bar B (Greenwich Village) A tiny standing bar with great happy hour and fun energy. No seats, but thatâ€™s part of the charm. Perfect for a quick bite before heading to dessert with friends.

Keens Steakhouse (Midtown)
Not a place Iâ€™d go alone, but perfect when family visits. Classic NYC steakhouse with rich dishes. Bonus: their desserts come from top bakeries like Eileenâ€™s Special Cheesecake â€” so you get the best without the line.

ğŸ° Desserts & CafÃ©s

Bibble & Sip (Midtown) Their cream puff is light, flavorful, and just indulgent enough â€” reminds me of the quality Iâ€™d expect in Asia. Yes, itâ€™s pricey, but a perfect homesick cure when youâ€™re craving something sweet and familiar.

Cha-An Teahouse (East Village)
A lovely matcha spot with thoughtful desserts and a calm, cozy atmosphere. Get there right when it opens to avoid a wait â€” it fills up quickly for good reason.

Anita La Mamma del Gelato (Upper West Side)
My go-to ice cream spot (been here over five times). Rich, creamy, and full of fun flavors. Still looking for something that beats The Franklin Fountain in Philly.

Venieroâ€™s Pasticceria & Caffe (East Village)
Old-school Italian cafÃ© with huge slices of cake and a cozy, uncrowded vibe. The cheesecake is solid. Not a â€œmust-go,â€ but a lovely stop if youâ€™re in the area after dinner.

ğŸŒ™ Late Night Eats

Katzâ€™s Delicatessen (Lower East Side)
A New York legend. Huge pastrami sandwiches and chaotic vintage vibes. Tip: Go after midnight after barâ€” theyâ€™re open 24/7, and youâ€™ll skip the crazy lines.

Double Chicken Please (Lower East Side)
This bar is crazy busy â€” I donâ€™t think Iâ€™d wait in that line again. But if youâ€™ve never been and youâ€™re curious, the tea-based cocktails are genuinely impressive. Itâ€™s rare to find cocktails with this kind of tea flavor and balance in the U.S. Worth trying onceâ€¦ if you have the patience.

ğŸ— Street Food

The Halal Guys (Midtown)
Iâ€™m not usually a street food person, but this one is famous. Just make sure you go to the right cart: the original one at 6th Avenue & W 53rd St (and the one directly across the street is also legit). Donâ€™t be fooled by other food trucks using the same name â€” theyâ€™re not quite the same. (This tip comes from someone who used to be a huge Halal Guys fan.) The combo platter with white sauce is the classic order.

After one year of eating my way through the city, I still donâ€™t feel like Iâ€™ve scratched the surface â€” but these places left an impression. Some brought comfort when I missed home, some surprised me, and some were just fun.
